keyTakeAways: The Menendez brothers, Lyle and Erik, were convicted in 1996 of murdering their parents, Jose and Kitty Menendez, in 1989.

The brothers have been serving life without parole for nearly 30 years, and Los Angeles District Attorney George Gascón is recommending a resentencing, citing changes in legal standards and new evidence of abuse by their father.

The 2023 habeas corpus petition by the brothers' attorneys included new evidence such as a sworn statement from Roy Rosselló about sexual abuse by Jose Menendez and a letter from Erik Menendez alluding to abuse.
Under California law, due to the brothers' age at the time of the crime, they may now be eligible for parole after serving a life sentence with the possibility of release if rehabilitated.
Gascón stated that the brothers have 'paid their debt to society' and have shown rehabilitation through community work, including efforts to support trauma recovery and inmate well-being.
The decision follows public interest generated by the Netflix series 'Monsters: The Lyle and Erik Menendez Story' and a new documentary featuring both brothers discussing their motivations.
Gascón emphasized that modern understandings of sexual abuse and sentencing reform make the reevaluation of the case 'brave and necessary,' and he denied it being a political move.
Kim Kardashian publicly supported the decision, calling it a step toward truth and fairness, and Jose Menendez’s niece called the move 'brave and necessary' for justice and family healing.
A hearing on the resentencing recommendation is expected within 30 to 45 days, though no final date has been set.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Los Angeles County District Attorney George Gascón has recommended that a judge resentence Lyle and Erik Menendez, brothers convicted in 1996 of murdering their parents Jose and Kitty Menendez in 1989. The recommendation, made after a 2023 habeas corpus petition presented new evidence of sexual abuse by their father and citing changes in legal standards and public understanding of trauma, would make the brothers eligible for parole under California’s youthful offender provisions. Gascón emphasized that the brothers have shown significant rehabilitation and have contributed positively to prison reform and trauma support programs. The decision follows heightened public attention from a Netflix series and documentary, and is supported by figures like Kim Kardashian and Jose Menendez’s niece, who called it a necessary step toward justice. A hearing on the recommendation is expected within 30 to 45 days, though no final date has been set.
title: Los Angeles District Attorney Recommends Resentencing in Decades-Old Menendez Brothers Murder Case
